results.title: Jumps and pole vaults
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Athletics”.
Slow-motion and stop-motion are used to demonstrate the running high jump, the running broad jump, the hop-step-and-jump, and the pole valut.

results.title: Jumping the gun
results.creator_credit: Jane Schneider, Murray Fahey and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Combining style from film noir, TV advertising imagery, Mills and Boon romance and Sydney ghetto realism, this is a farcical look at how one woman’s “morning after” fantasy turns into a tragi-comic nightmare.

results.title: Jumping molecules!
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Landmark Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
Konrad, the kitchen robot, shows how the energy in heat may be used to demonstrate the fundamentals of physics. Focuses on temperature and presents experiments using common household materials involving the kitchen refrigerator, cold water and hot water.

results.title: Jumping for Joy
results.creator_credit: Stanley Russell, Educational Films of Scotland and Thames and Clyde Film Company
results.brief_description: An introduction to trampolining. A semi-instructional film, it shows the growing popularity of the five basic landing positions, and shows suitable exercises for people of different ages. A section on the value of trampolining in rehabilitation work is also included.

results.title: Jumpin' Jack Flash (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Penny Marshall, Joel Silver, Lawrence Gordon and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Whoopi Goldberg stars in this action adventure comedy hit. There’s music, murder, mayhem and a lot of laughs as she tries to save an endangered spy operative, code-named Jack - even though she’s never met him! Now the CIA and the KGB have her jumpin’ and the world may never be the same.

results.title: Jumpcut
results.brief_description: Two pieces of found footage were used to produce ‘Jumpcut’, a series of frames cut from the head and tails of various takes of a talking head shot for a 1970s industrial film or commercial; and a piece of 1950s/60s home movie footage depicting a jumping child interrupted by the perforation marks at the end of the reel. Both images are processed through the Cox Box. The loop of the jumping boy had developed, over time, a network of miniscule cracks in the emulsion which were further emphasised by the increased contrast of the processing and the slow motion.
results.description: Two pieces of found footage were used to produce ‘Jumpcut’, a series of frames cut from the head and tails of various takes of a talking head shot for a 1970s industrial film or commercial; and a piece of 1950s/60s home movie footage depicting a jumping child interrupted by the perforation marks at the end of the reel. Both images are processed through the Cox Box. The loop of the jumping boy had developed, over time, a network of miniscule cracks in the emulsion which were further emphasised by the increased contrast of the processing and the slow motion.

Both images are processed through the Cox Box. results.title: Jump the fence
results.creator_credit: Natalie Green, Lucy MacLaren and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Two young girls who feel restricted at home decide to escape in a gelati van. After a short burst of freedom they end up in Winlaton, a girls’ training centre.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basketball Skills”.
One in a series of films on basketball skills, giving instruction and demonstration of basketball techniques, including slow-motion action and training routines. Narrated by Ron Pickering.
